quick_summary: Locks EVERYONE out of the file, including you! It becomes a 'ghost file' - visible but completely inaccessible. You'll need sudo to fix it.

parts.meaning: Permission code: NOBODY gets ANY permissions (not even you!)
The file you're about to turn into a ghost - visible but untouchable

translation: Remove all permissions from everyone, including yourself. The file becomes inaccessible.
halloween_analogy: It's like locking yourself out of your own house, throwing away the key, and then realizing your phone is inside. The house is still there, you can see it, but you can't get in without calling a locksmith (sudo).
safe_alternatives: chmod 400 file.txt - Read-only for owner (you can still read it)
chmod 600 file.txt - Owner can read and write (private file)
chmod 444 file.txt - Everyone can read, nobody can write
Use encryption for truly sensitive files, not permission tricks
If you accidentally chmod 000, fix it with: sudo chmod 644 filename
Remember: 000 means no permissions for anyone, including you!
